title: Rugby World Cup star lists luxury home on Airbnb
text:
Rugby World Cup star lists luxury home on Airbnb Last updated 11:32, September 2 2015 Airbnb 
Former England rugby player Lewis Moody has listed his home on Airbnb for the Rugby World Cup. 
Former Rugby World Cup winning player Lewis Moody has opened his home to Airbnb users for the duration of the Rugby World Cup - although if you're an All Blacks supporter you might want to give this one a miss. 
The former flanker is offering users of the popular accommodation site, which allows travellers to stay in unique locations around the world, a chance to enjoy the spoils of his four-bedroom home in the quaint English county of Wiltshire, for just £150 (NZ$363) per night. 
READ MORE * Airbnb gives rugby fans chance to sleep over at Eden Park Airbnb 
The property is not far from The Recreation Ground, Bath Rugby's official stadium. A stadium which is often regarded as one of the most 'idyllic' grounds in England. 
Moody will also offer the lucky tenants a private rugby lesson in his sprawling backyard, complete with its own mini rugby goal-posts. 
The stately home offers two queen bedrooms, a double, twin and three bathrooms, complete with walk-in showers.

The stately home offers two queen bedrooms, a double, twin and three bathrooms all offering walk-in showers. 
The location of the home also gives visitors the perfect chance to explore the beautiful city of Bath. 
Historic Bath was designated a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1987 due to the city's exquisite Georgian architecture and well-preserved Roman remnants. 
'The World Cup is going to be an amazing experience for competitors and spectators alike and I'm keen to share it with as many people as possible – and what better way than to open up my own home?!' Moody wrote on his listing . 
As with most Airbnb rentals, the property comes with its own set of rules. No pets, parties (unless England win the Rugby World Cup) and no All Blacks fans are allowed at the house with Moody imposing a blanket ban on the wearing of All Blacks or Welsh rugby shirts on his property. Ad Feedback 
Performing of the haka is also strictly banned. Instead residents will be forced to sing 'God Save The Queen' at 8am every morning. 
The renting of Moody's house also comes with a bit of charitable joy. All proceeds from the rental go to the Lewis Moody Foundation, a charity that provides special wishes for terminally ill children.
